comments:
The topics of this calculus-based course are electric and magnetic fields; Coulomb's, Ampere's, and Faraday's laws; Maxwell's equations; emission, propagation, and absorption of electromagnetic radiation; interference, reflection, refraction, scattering, and diffraction phenomena.  This course is PHYS 151 without the lab component.

Overall, students found this course to be very difficult and a lot of work, but very worthwhile because they felt that the material was “relevant to things we see everyday.” This made the extra work not a waste of time.   One student noted that it was a “science course I’ve learned the most… from this far.”  

Students overwhelmingly had very positive reviews of Professor Sako.  The majority agreed that Professor Sako was a “great professor.”  Some even went so far as to describe him as “the best professor of physics at this university” and the “most amazing professor ever.”  Students also said Professor Sako was “extremely clear and communicates well.”  Professor Sako was extremely passionate about the material, “explaining the topics thoroughly and doing everything in his power to help his students excel.”  Students felt he not only was a great lecturer, but also “truly cares about his students.”

Students did not highly recommend this course for non-majors.  Students felt that the course was “manageable with hard work,” but one student felt it was “extremely difficult to keep up with the coursework.”  PHYS 150 or PHYS 170 is a prerequisite for this course.
